Option 1 Option 2 Option 3 Code: ```html label input type="radio" name="grp" value="1" Option 1 /label label input type="radio" name="grp" value="2" checked Option 2 /label label input type="radio" name="grp" value="3" Option 3 /label ``` 3. Select Dropdowns Enhanced Value Added: Theming: Applies site theme colors to the dropdown trigger. Clearable: Adds a clear button (x) if data-clearable is present. Searchable: Adds search capabilities if data-searchable is present. Variants: Supports data-variant (success, error) and data-size (sm, lg). Chocolate Sprinkles Nuts Sizes Small Small Select Large Large Select Code: ```html !-- Standard -- select option Apple /option option Banana /option /select !-- Clearable -- select data-clearable option value="" Select... /option option Chocolate /option /select !-- Static Theme Variants (visible without selection) -- select data-variant="success" style="border-color: var(--success-color); background-color: rgba(34, 197, 94, 0.1);" option ‚úì Valid Option /option /select select data-variant="error" style="border-color: var(--danger-color); background-color: rgba(239

WB Behaviors is a lightweight, modular web component library built on native browser APIs. It provides a set of behaviors and custom elements that enhance your HTML without heavy dependencies. To get started, simply include the WB bootstrap script and start using wb-* custom elements or x-* behavior attributes on your existing HTML. The framework automatically discovers and initializes components, making it easy to progressively enhance your pages. This card starts in the expanded state. Click 'Show Less' to collapse it. documents.title: Framework Integration Demo
documents.content: Framework Integration Demo ‚Üê Back to Home Framework Agnostic Demos WB Behaviors work with any framework because they rely on standard HTML attributes. The framework handles the DOM, and WB handles the behavior. The WB Advantage Universal Compatibility Write your behavior logic once using standard HTML attributes. It works identically in React, Vue, Svelte, or plain HTML. Zero Lock-in Switching frameworks? Your UI behaviors stay the same. No need to rewrite tooltips, ripples, or validation logic. Performance First Tiny footprint. Behaviors are lazy-loaded only when needed. No heavy hydration costs for simple interactions. Progressive Enhancement Built on standard HTML. If JavaScript fails or hasn't loaded, your semantic HTML remains accessible and functional. React React Integration This button is rendered by React. The x-* behavior attributes are passed as standard props. Code used in this demo: import React, { useState, useEffect } from 'react'; import ReactDOM from 'react-dom/client'; import WB from 'wb-behaviors'; const e = React.createElement; function ReactApp() { // Initialize WB when component mounts useEffect(() => { WB.init(); }, []); const [count, setCount] = useState(0); return e('div', { style: { padding: '1rem', border: '1px dashed #61dafb', borderRadius: '8px' } }, [ e('h3', { key: 'h3' }, `React Counter: ${count}`), e('button', { key: 'btn', className: 'wb-btn-gradient', 'x-ripple': '', 'x-tooltip': '', 'x-toast': '', 'data-tooltip': 'I am a React button!', 'data-message': `Count is now ${count + 1}`, 'data-type': 'info', onClick: () => setCount(c => c + 1) }, 'Increment + WB Magic ‚ú®') ]); } const root = ReactDOM.createRoot(document.getElementById('react-root')); root.render(e(ReactApp)); Vue 3 Vue Integration This section is a Vue app. WB attributes are bound just like any other attribute. Vue Message: {{ message }} Reverse Message (Vue + WB) Code used in this demo: div id="vue-app" div style="padding: 1rem; border: 1px dashed #42b883; border-radius: 8px;" h3 Vue Message: {{ message }} /h3 input v-model="message" class="wb-input-glass" placeholder="Type here..." style="margin-bottom: 1rem; width: 100%;" button class="wb-btn-glass" x-ripple x-tooltip :data-tooltip="'Current length: ' + message.length" @click="reverseMessage" Reverse Message (Vue + WB) /button /div /div script import { createApp, ref, onMounted } from 'vue'; import WB from 'wb-behaviors'; createApp({ setup() { // Initialize WB when component mounts onMounted(() => { WB.init(); }); const message = ref('Hello Vue!'); const reverseMessage = () => { message.value = message.value.split('').reverse().join(''); }; return { message, reverseMessage }; } }).mount('#vue-app'); /script Svelte Svelte Integration In Svelte, you just add the attributes to your markup. No special bindings needed. Note: This example requires a Svelte build step. script import WB from 'wb-behaviors'; import { onMount } from 'svelte'; onMount(() => { WB.init(); }); let count = 0; function handleClick() { count += 1; } /script button class="wb-btn-gradient" x-ripple x-tooltip data-tooltip="Count: {count}" on:click={handleClick} Svelte Button /button Angular Angular Integration In Angular, use standard attribute binding. WB behaviors initialize automatically. Note: This example requires an Angular build step. import { Component, OnInit } from '@angular/core'; import WB from 'wb-behaviors'; @Component({ selector: 'app-demo', template: ` button class="wb-btn-gradient" x-ripple x-tooltip [attr.data-tooltip]="'Count: ' + count" (click)="increment()" Angular Button /button ` }) export class DemoComponent implements OnInit { count = 0; ngOnInit() { WB.init(); } increment() { this.count++; } } SolidJS SolidJS Integration SolidJS uses fine-grained reactivity. Initialize WB in onMount . Note: This example requires a SolidJS build step. import { createSignal, onMount } from 'solid-js'; import WB from 'wb-behaviors'; function Counter() { const [count, setCount] = createSignal(0); onMount(() => { WB.init(); }); return ( button class="wb-btn-gradient" x-ripple x-tooltip data-tooltip={`Count: ${count()}`} onClick={() => setCount(c => c + 1)} SolidJS Button /button ); } HTMX HTMX Integration HTMX swaps HTML from the server. Use htmx:afterSwap to re-scan new content. Click Me (HTMX) Code used in this demo: !-- HTMX loads content, WB enhances it -- button hx-post="/clicked" hx-swap="outerHTML" class="wb-btn-gradient" x-ripple x-tooltip data-tooltip="I ripple locally, but fetch remotely!" Click Me /button script // Re-initialize WB after HTMX swaps content document.body.addEventListener('htmx:afterSwap', (evt) => { // Only scan the new content for better performance WB.scan(evt.detail.target); }); /script

documents.title: PCE (Pseudo-Custom Elements) Test
documents.content: PCE (Pseudo-Custom Elements) Test PCE Test Suite What is this? This page demonstrates Pseudo-Custom Elements (PCE) . Instead of using standard HTML with x-behavior attributes (e.g., div x-behavior="card" ), we use custom tag names like profile-card . How it works The core library ( wb-lazy.js ) maintains a mapping of these custom tags to their corresponding behaviors. The process is fully automated: Detection: The IntersectionObserver (lazy) or initial scan (eager) identifies the custom tag in the DOM. Lookup: The system checks the customElementMappings registry to find which behavior module (e.g., cardprofile ) matches the tag (e.g., profile-card ). Dynamic Import: The JavaScript module for that behavior is fetched only if it hasn't been loaded yet . This keeps the initial page load fast. Hydration: The behavior function is called with the element as its argument. It utilizes the properties defined in data- attributes to render internal HTML, apply CSS classes, and attach event listeners in-place. Note: Unlike native Web Components, this does not use Shadow DOM. The element is enhanced in standard DOM, preserving global styles and simplicity while offering a component-like developer experience. Is the startup quicker? Yes. Traditional frameworks often download a large "bundle" of JavaScript containing every possible component before the page can start. This approach uses Lazy Loading : Initial Load: Only the tiny core library ( wb-lazy.js ) is downloaded. On Scroll: The code for profile-card is ignored until you actually scroll it into view. Result: Near-instant page startup, even with hundreds of available component types. Behind the Scenes The registry in src/core/wb-lazy.js defines these mappings: const customElementMappings = [ { selector: 'profile-card', behavior: 'cardprofile' }, { selector: 'hero-card', behavior: 'cardhero' }, { selector: 'stats-card', behavior: 'cardstats' }, // ... and so on ]; Configuration Attributes on the custom element are automatically passed to the behavior function as configuration. For example: profile-card data-name="Sarah" is functionally equivalent to div x-behavior="cardprofile" data-name="Sarah" . This allows for a cleaner, more semantic HTML syntax while maintaining the benefits of the behavior-driven architecture (lazy loading, encapsulation, separation of concerns). Verifying that custom tags automatically inject behaviors. 1. Profile Card ( profile-card ) 2. Hero Card ( hero-card ) 3. Stats Card ( stats-card ) 4. Testimonial Card ( testimonial-card ) 5. Video Card ( video-card ) 6. File Card ( file-card ) 7. Notification Card ( notification-card ) 8. Phase 2 Tags This is a basic card. 9. Interactive Elements Hover & Click Me (Custom Element) Hover & Click Me (Generic Attribute) Hover Me (Span) Ripple Button (Attribute) Success Badge

Use it TWO ways: -- wb-view badge-tag variant="primary" New /wb-view !-- wrapper syntax -- badge-tag variant="primary" New /badge-tag !-- auto-registered tag -- !-- 3. Both produce: -- span class="badge-tag badge-tag--primary" New /span Custom elements require a hyphen (Web Components spec). WB Views handles this automatically: View Name Has Hyphen? Custom Tag toolbar No wb-toolbar (auto-prefixed) card No wb-card (auto-prefixed) alert-box Yes alert-box (as-is) stat-tile Yes stat-tile (as-is) nav-link Yes nav-link (as-is) The Rule: No hyphen ‚Üí auto-prefix with wb- | Has hyphen ‚Üí use as-is template wb-view="component-tile" div class="tile" span class="tile__icon" {{icon}} /span span class="tile__label" slot {{text}} /slot /span span class="tile__badge" wb-if="badge" {{badge}} /span /div /template template wb-view="alert-box" div class="alert alert--{{variant || 'info'}}" span class="alert__icon" wb-if="icon" {{icon}} /span div class="alert__content" div class="alert__heading" wb-if="heading" {{heading}} /div div class="alert__message" {{message}} /div /div button class="alert__dismiss" wb-if="dismissible" ‚úï /button /div /template template wb-view="stat-tile" div class="stat" span class="stat__icon" wb-if="icon" {{icon}} /span div div class="stat__value" {{value}} /div div class="stat__label" slot {{text}} /slot /div div class="stat__trend stat__trend--{{trend}}" wb-if="trendValue" {{trendValue}} /div /div /div /template template wb-view="badge-tag" span class="badge-tag badge-tag--{{variant || 'primary'}}" span wb-if="icon" {{icon}} /span slot {{text}} /slot /span /template template wb-view="tag-list" div class="tags" span class="tag" wb-for="tag in tags" {{tag}} /span /div /template template wb-view="user-card" div class="user-card" wb-avatar initials="{{initials}}" size="lg" status="{{status}}" /wb-avatar div class="user-card__info" div class="user-card__name" {{name}} /div div class="user-card__role" {{role}} /div /div slot /slot /div /template Pro Away Update your account settings and preferences below.

documents.title: wb-views-demo
documents.content: # WB Views Demo documentation This document outlines the features and components demonstrated in [wb-views-demo.html](wb-views-demo.html). ## Overview The WB Views system is a **Custom Element Factory** that allows developers to define HTML templates and automatically register them as fully functional Web Components. **Key Definition:** Define a template once ‚Üí get a custom tag automatically. Change the template ‚Üí ALL instances update. ## Core Concepts ### 1. Defining a View Views are defined using standard HTML ` ` tags with the `wb-view` attribute: ```html {{title}} ``` ### 2. Using a View Once defined (or loaded from registry), views can be used as standard HTML tags: ```html This is the body content. ``` ### 3. Template Syntax - **Slots**: ` ` elements are replaced by the component's inner HTML. Named slots ` ` match children with `slot="header"`. - **Interpolation**: `{{variable}}` injects attribute values. - **Conditionals**: `wb-if="prop"` renders element only if `prop` is truthy. - **Loops**: `wb-for="item in list"` repeats the element for each item in the array. - **Defaults**: content inside ` default ` is shown if no content is provided. ## Components Registry The demo showcases components defined in `src/wb-views/views-registry.json`. ### Basic Controls * **Buttons**: ` `, ` ` (Supports variants: primary, secondary, success, error, etc.) * **Badges**: ` `, ` ` * **Avatars**: ` ` (Supports initials or images, status dots) ### Layout & Containers * **Cards**: ` `, ` ` (Composition examples) * **Sections**: ` ` * **Toolbars**: ` `, ` ` * **Alerts**: ` ` ### Data & Feedback * **Stats**: ` `, ` ` * **Example Blocks**: ` ` (Used in the demo to show source code) * **Loading**: ` ` ## Setup The system is initialized via JavaScript module import: ```javascript // Initialize views system const { initViews } = await import('../src/core/wb-views.js'); await initViews({ registry: '../src/wb-views/views-registry.json' }); ``` ## Styling This demo page uses: 1. `src/styles/themes.css`: CSS Variables for theming (Colors, Spacing). 2. `src/styles/site.css`: Base component styles (Buttons, Layouts). 3. `demos/wb-views-demo.css`: Demo-specific layout overrides.
